sec.p: This study was carried out at Wytham Woods (51°46′N, 1°20′W, National Grid Reference SP4608), a 385‐ha mixed‐deciduous woodland in Oxfordshire, UK. The canopy composition of the Wytham is primarily pedunculate oak ( Quercus robur), common ash ( Fraxinus excelsior), sycamore maple ( Acer pseudoplatanu, European beech ( Fagus sylvatica), and silver birch ( Betula pendula), with an understory of common hazel ( Corylus avellana), hawthorn ( Crataegus momgyna), elder ( Sambucus niger), and field maple ( Acer campestre) (Perrins, 1965). Wytham Woods consists of a mosaic of habitat types that can be broadly categorized as (1) ancient seminatural woodland, (2) secondary regeneration, (3) nineteenth‐century broadleaf plantation, and (4) twentieth‐century plantation and is located on a hill (altitude range 60–170 m above sea level). Soil type varies across the site, with thin soil over corallian limestone at higher altitudes, and the lower slopes consisting of deeper clay soil and sandy soil (Savill et al., 2010).
